H0.text: Aphasia is the medical term for the inability to use or understand what, resulting from damage to the brain. Speech

H1.text: Aphasia is the medical term for the inability to use or understand what, resulting from damage to the brain. Memory

H2.text: Aphasia is the medical term for the inability to use or understand what, resulting from damage to the brain. Motor Skills

H3.text: Aphasia is the medical term for the inability to use or understand what, resulting from damage to the brain. Lnguage

A4.text: Receptive aphasia (also known as 'sensory aphasia' or 'Wernicke's aphasia'), which is characterized by fluent speech, but marked difficulties understanding words and sentences.

A5.text: Cognitive deficits, such as attention and working memory constitute the underlying cause of language impairment in people with aphasia.

A6.text: People with a lesion to this area develop expressive aphasia, meaning that they know what they want to say, they just cannot get it out.

A7.text: Both expressive and receptive aphasia also affect the use of sign language, in analogous ways to how they affect speech, with expressive aphasia causing signers to sign slowly and with incorrect grammar, whereas a signer with receptive aphasia will sign fluently, but make little sense to others and have difficulties comprehending others' signs.
